name: Recover From Exhaustion
summary: Remove a level of the Exhausted condition.
description: During a long rest in which you consume food and drink, you can use a long rest action to reduce your @Compendium[undertaking.conditions.ERBR3AG01H4N1L91]{Exhaustion} by 1 level.

name: Identify Magic Item
summary: Attempt to discern the effects of a possible magic item.
description:
In the realm of magic items there are those that are nearly identical to their non-magical twins, and others that put their magic properties on display for the world. There are times that magic items have hints as to what their magical properties might be on them. Some might have telling markings or engravings, glow or even have a command word listed on its body. Magical properties can even manifest physical ways, such as a feeling of connection or dread while holding it.

Wearing or experimenting with a magic item can be a useful way of figuring out what a magic item is capable of, so long as the item does not require attunement, though this method can take a good bit longer. If a character is unable to determine if an item is magical, they can still attempt to attune to it. However, they do not know if they successfully attuned, and are not given any information on what the item does or the effects it has without further experimentation or full identification.

However, many magical items are indistinguishable from non-magical items. If the item is suspected of being a magic item, the creature can attempt to identify it.

The fastest way to figure out how a magic item works is through casting Identify. However, a character can attempt to identify the magical properties of one item as a long rest action. At the end of the rest, the character learns if the item is magical, and makes an Intelligence (Arcana) check (or a Wisdom (Theology) check if more religious than arcane) if so. The item’s rarity determines the DC as seen below.

Magic Item Identification Table

Rarity

Identification DC

Common

DC 10

Uncommon

DC 15

Rare

DC 20

Very Rare

DC 25

Legendary

DC 30

Artifact

Impossible

Upon succeeding the identification check, the character learns all magical aspects of the magic item, including its name, how to use it, any activation words, if it requires attunement, and so on. They can also attune to the item as part of this process.

Upon failure, the identification fails and the item remains a mystery. The character may reattempt the identification on their next long rest.

name: Prepare Meal
summary: Prepare a meal for a small group and bolster their spirits.
description: As a Rest Action, Provided you have access to sufficient supplies, you can prepare a meal or drinks. Up to three people, including yourself, can have a serving during a rest to gain 1d4 temporary hit points.

name: Repair Vehicle
summary: Restore hit points to a damaged vehicle.
description: As a Rest Action, make an Intelligence (Craft) check. Restore the vehicle’s hit points by the result, so long as you have the parts.

name: Tune-Up
summary: Prepare a vehicle to endure wear or hostile conditions.
description:
As a Long Rest Action, you can tune up a vehicle to give one of the following benefits. Should the vehicle take any damage, be used to travel for a cumulative full day, or travel over rough terrain for half the length, the benefit is removed.

  • Lubricate: Increase movement speed of vehicle by ¼ rounded up to the nearest 5 feet. In addition, reduce travel time by 1 day per 6 days of travel.
  • Reinforce: Increase the vehicle’s durability. Make an Intelligence (Craft) check, giving the vehicle temporary hit points equal to the result.
  • Weather Proof: Increase the vehicle’s resilience to one type of intense weather. Vehicles can add your Intelligence (Craft) modifier to checks relating to the vehicle avoiding the detriments of the weather.
  • Terrain Match: Prepare a vehicle for particularly intense weather, so long as you have fitting parts. Vehicles can add your Intelligence (Craft) modifier to checks relating to the vehicle traveling across rough terrain.

name: Create Potion Base
summary: Prepare a vial of potion base, useful for further brewing.
description: As a Long Rest Action, you can turn a vial of Distilled Water into a Potion Base using your Alchemy Kit and a few base chemicals that come with it.

name: Brew Healing Potion
requirements: Alchemy Kit, Potion Base, Herb, Creature Part
summary: Attempt to brew a healing potion from various ingredients.
description:
• As a Long Rest Action, you can attempt to combine a vial of Potion Base and combine it with any herbal ingredient and creature part to make one vial of Healing Potion. When you do so, roll an Intelligence (Craft) check. On success, the potion is made with both effects. 
    • The rarity of the herbal ingredient determines the DC, as shown in the Healing Potion Brewing DC table.
    • The rarity of the creature part determines the potency of the potion, as shown in the Potion Potency table.
    • Healing Potions are always instantaneous and single-usage.

Healing Potion Brewing DC

Ingredient

Common Herb

Uncommon Herb

Rare Herb

Brewing DC

DC 16

DC 11

DC 6

Potion Potency

Creature Part CR

CR 0-4

CR 5-9

CR 10-15

CR 15-20

CR 20+

Duration

6 seconds

1 minute

1 hour

8 hours

Indefinite

Potency

1d4+1

2d4+2

4d4+4

8d4+8

10d4+20

name: Brew Advanced Potion
requirements: Alchemy Kit, Potion Base, Herb, Creature Part
summary: Attempt to brew a potion with unique effects based on its ingredients.
description:
As a Long Rest Action, you can take a vial of Potion Base, an herbal ingredient, and a creature part, and turn it into a full potion. This process includes preparing the ingredients and mixing them into the Potion Base before leaving it to sit and combine, with occasional stirring, over the full length of the rest. The result is a single-use potion with an effect provided by the ingredients used. When you do so, roll an Intelligence (Craft) check of DC 10. On success, the potion is made with both effects. On failure, the potion is made, but the monster part effect is not applied and is lost.

  • Herbal Ingredient: Herbal ingredients differ in effect per biome collected in. Within each biome are Common, Uncommon, and Rare varieties, each with unique base effects. Unless specified otherwise, herbs are assumed to fall into these categories. See the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.5R8FKYXDXRVWMOQD]{Ingredients - Herbs} table for effects per herbal biome and rarity.
    • When a creature is afflicted by a potion with a negative effect, that creature can make a Constitution (Save) check against the potion’s DC, as determined by its rarity on the Potion Potency table. On a successful save, the creature is unaffected.
    • Unless specified otherwise, markets located in or adjacent to certain biomes tend to have good access to common herbs. Uncommon herbs may be found, but often at a price. Rare herbs almost always need to be found manually or at an excessive premium. The further from a biome, the more the price multiplies.
  • Creature Part: Creature parts are based on the Creature Type and Challenge Rating of the creature the part came from. The former determines the effects of the potion as listed in the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.01V3FGYMA3LZKZ1N]{Potion Ingredients - Creature Parts} table. The latter determines the potency of the potion as listed in the Potion Potency table. 
  • Imbibing Speed: The viscosity of potions can vary, some potions taking a Minor Action, and some requiring a full Action, as listed in the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.5R8FKYXDXRVWMOQD]{Ingredients - Herbs} table.

Potion Potency

Creature Part CR

CR 0-4

CR 5-9

CR 10-15

CR 15-20

CR 20+

Duration

6 seconds

1 minute

1 hour

8 hours

Indefinite

Potency

1d4+1

2d4+2

4d4+4

8d4+8

10d4+20

name: Create Art
requirements: Art Kit, Art Supplies worth at least 1gp
summary: Create a new work of art that falls within your specialization.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can create one piece of art no larger than 5 square feet that you could reasonably create with your specialization. The first rest you spend creating the work of art, make an Intelligence (Craft) check. The result of the check is its initial @Compendium[undertaking.tables.SVAINSJV86RZ4629]{Art Quality} level, which determines the base selling price of the art piece. The initial creation of an art piece takes up 5gp worth of supplies.

  • You can attempt to make an art piece with less than 5gp worth of supplies for a -1 to your Intelligence (Craft) checks, and a further -1 for each 5sp less than 5gp, to a minimum of 1gp. For example, using supplies worth a bit more than 2gp will confer a -6 on your Intelligence (Craft) check.

name: Refine Art
summary: Refine an existing work of art that falls within your specialization.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can refine one piece of art that you could reasonably create with your specialization. You can refine a piece of art over the course of multiple rests, but an art piece can only be refined up to 5 times total. Each refinement costs an additional 5gp worth of art supplies. Each time you attempt to refine a piece of art, reduce the quality level by 10, and then make an Intelligence (Craft) check and add it to the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.SVAINSJV86RZ4629]{Art Quality} level. Based on the resulting quality level, the price of the art further increases.

  • Fine Art: Art over a certain quality level is considered Fine Art. A creature of intelligence 6 or higher may gain a one-time benefit upon spending 1 minute observing the piece for the first time. Receiving the effect from a Fine Art piece gives you the option to take the effect of a lower quality piece as well. A creature cannot receive the bonus from more than one Fine Art piece at once.
  • You can attempt to refine an art piece with less than 5gp worth of supplies for a -1 to your Intelligence (Craft) checks, and a further -1 for each 5sp less than 5gp. For example, using supplies worth a bit more than 2gp will confer a -6 on your Intelligence (Craft) check.

name: Craft Artisanal
summary: Create or continue working on an item related to your specialization.
description: You can create one non-magical object, item, or piece of clothing that you could reasonably build with your specialization. So long as you have relevant materials equal to ¾ of the item’s cost, you can work on creating the item over the course of multiple rests. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check against DC 10. Each success counts as 1 completed work session, a failure does not. Depending on the item’s actual cost, it takes more work sessions to complete (see @Compendium[undertaking.tables.WS5UX4KFBB0PAZAE]{Craft Artisanal} table).

name: Repair Artisanal
summary: Repair a fully or partially broken item related to your specialization.
description: So long as it is something you could build with your specialization, you can repair a fully broken object or item at ½ the material cost in ½ the sessions using the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.WS5UX4KFBB0PAZAE]{Craft Artisanal} table. Partially damaged objects require fewer parts and less time to repair, ask your GM for the difficulty and cost of a partial repair. Intelligence (Craft) checks to repair parts have a DC of 12.

name: Modify Artisanal
summary: Improve the value of an item related to your specialization.
description: As a Rest Action, you can modify one non-magical object, item, structure, or piece of clothing in a way that you could reasonably do with your specialization, or else painting, dying, trimming, or smoothing it. When you do so, make an Intelligence (Craft) check. If half the result is higher than the gold cost of the materials added to the object, you succeed. If not, you may continue adding to your roll with each subsequent attempt until you have met the gold cost of the object. On success, apply the modification and increase the selling price of the item by 1.5 times the external materials used or applied as part of the process. The price of the object cannot more than double the price of either the applied materials or object.

name: Craft Cloth or Leather Armor
summary: (Cloth/Leatherworking Only) Create a piece of cloth or leather armor.
description: If your specialization is in leatherworking or cloth work, you can craft one piece of non-magical leather or cloth armor. So long as you have relevant materials equal to ¾ of the armor’s cost, you can work on creating the item over the course of multiple rests. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check against DC 10. Each success counts as 1 completed work session, a failure does not. Depending on the item’s actual cost, it takes more work sessions to complete (see @Compendium[undertaking.tables.WS5UX4KFBB0PAZAE]{Craft Artisanal} table).

name: Find Herbs
summary: Search the local area for any medicinal herbs that grow here.
description:
Over the course of an hour, you can attempt to find herbs in a biome. Roll an Intelligence (Nature) check. Based on the result and environment, you find different results. If you get a high roll, you can choose to find a more common herb instead.
Certain biomes are harder to find herbs in. Those biomes have DC modifiers listed next to their names on the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.5R8FKYXDXRVWMOQD]{Ingredients - Herbs} table.

Herb Finding Table

Ingredient

Common Herb

Uncommon Herb

Rare Herb

Finding DC

DC 13

DC 15

DC 18

Yield

1d6-1 (Minimum of 1)

1d4

1

name: Agriculture
summary: Plant the seeds of an herb for greater yields at a later date.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can plant seeds in a 5 ft area of prepared soil. So long as it isn’t dying, the plant grows over the course of months, but their output is greatly multiplied.
In their natural biome, plants survive so long as they are treated once a week. Outside of their natural biome, they generally survive so long as they are treated once a day, so long as they are shielded from the more extreme elements of the biome, such as heat or cold.

  • Common Flora: 
    • Yield: x20 per 5ft.
    • Harvest Period: 1 month.
  • Uncommon Flora: 
    • Yield: x10 per 5ft.
    • Harvest Period: 2 months.
  • Rare Flora: 
    • Yield x5 per 5ft.
    • Harvest Period: 3 months.

name: Treat Plant
summary: Tend to a plant, ensuring it remains healthy and continues to grow.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can treat up to a 10 ft area worth of plants, watering and trimming them, and keeping their soil clean and pest-free. This process uses up a pint of water per 5 ft area.
If used on a plant creature, it restores 1d6 additional hit points as part of the rest, but uses up 4 pints of water.

name: Fortify Structure
summary: Repair a structure and make it more resistant to destruction.
description:
So long as you have relevant materials, you can reinforce a structure against damage at a rate of 10sqft per minute. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check.

  • If the structure has hit points, restore them by the result of the check - 10.
  • If the structure has a DC to destroy it, take the result of the check - 5. If that is higher than the DC, that becomes the new DC to destroy it.

name: Prepare Rations
summary: Prepare food to last longer without spoiling, making suitable rations.
description: As a Rest Action, you can dry and store food, turning up to up to 3 pounds of food into 3 days of rations. Food lasts significantly longer as rations, but any benefits granted by the food beyond sustenance are removed upon becoming rations.

name: Brew Alcohol
summary: Prepare a new batch of or continue refining a fermenting beverage.
description:
Provided you have access to sufficient supplies, you can brew alcohol over the course of multiple long rests. You can work on the brew over a Rest Action, but no more than once per completed long rest. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check against DC 15. Each success improves the quality of the brew as shown in the table below. Regardless of the quality, the batch is completed after 5 rests spent working on it, and will brew enough for three full servings. A serving takes a Rest Action to consume and gain all the benefits.

  • Further fermenting past its completion may improve the flavor or alcohol levels, but it can no longer be worked to gain additional effects.
  • Larger brewing containers are generally too cumbersome for traveling kits, but can be used to make larger batches if that is not a concern.
  • Forcing a serving down in a shorter time than a Rest Action, no faster than an action, reduces the effects granted by the brew by 2 success levels. So if it was a 3 success level brew, then you would only gain the benefits of a 1 success level brew.

Brewing Table

Successes

0

1

2

3

4

5

Effect

Counts as a meal

Also gain 1d4 temporary hit points

Also remove the Frightened condition and gain advantage on Save Checks against the Frightened condition for the next hour

Also regain an extra Rest Die

Also gain 1d10+2 temporary hit points, stacking on top of any previous temporary hit points

Also gain +1 on all saving throws until your next long rest

name: Tonight's Entertainment
summary: Perform for a group to chase their worries away for a bit.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can put on a performance to get your mind off of things. When you do, choose to either add a +1 to all skill checks made during this rest (aside from this one) or, before your next rest, add a +1 to a single check’s final result.
In addition, make a Presence (Perform) check. Take the result divided by 5 and rounded down. Choose that many other creatures resting nearby to gain the same choice of entertainment bonus.
Should you roll a Natural 20 on, all creatures gain both bonuses. In addition, choose one member of the rest, other than yourself, to gain a point of Luck.

name: Fashion a Rod
requirements: Branch or Pole, 10ft of Rope or String
summary: Create a makeshift fishing rod from available materials.
description: As a Rest Action, you can create a Poor Fishing Rod using any wooden branch or pole and 10ft of either rope or string.

name: Fashion a Net
summary: Create a makeshift fishing net from available materials.
description: As a Long Rest Action, you can weave and tie 50ft of rope into a Net suitable for fishing.

name: Gather Bait
summary: Collect tiny creatures suitable for use as fishing bait.
description: As a Rest Action in any location with vegetation, you can search for insects and invertebrates that are suitable for use as fishing bait. Make an Intelligence (Nature) check against DC 8. On a success, you find 1d4 Fishing Bait. You find 1 additional piece of Fishing Bait for every 3 your roll exceeds the DC by.

name: Set a Trap
summary: Bait a net or cage to catch a large number of fish at once.
description: As a Long Rest Action within a short walk of a body of water or liquid, you can use up to 3 pieces of Fishing Bait (which are consumed) and either a net or small cage in order to catch multiple fish. If the body of water you set the trap in contains fish, you are able to attract 1d4 fish for each piece of bait you used. When hauling in the trap, you capture all of the fish that were attracted with a successful Strength (Athletics) or Wisdom (Instinct) check against DC 12. On a failure, you only catch half of the fish and the rest escape. Each fish you catch can be cooked to feed one creature.

name: Prize Fishing
summary: Cast a line and try to reel in an impressive catch.
description:
As a Rest Action next to a body of water or liquid, or a Long Rest Action within a short walk from one, you can attempt to catch an exceptional fish. In order to fish in this way, you need to be holding a fishing rod and expend one piece of fishing bait. Each use of this action is resolved in the following steps:

  • Gear Up: Your current fishing score for this attempt starts equal to the base fishing score of the rod you are using.
  • Pick a Spot: Increase your current fishing score by 1d4.
  • Cast Your Line: Make a Strength (Athletics) check against DC 12. On a success, increase your current fishing score by 1. On a failure, decrease it by 1 instead.
  • Settle In: Choose any prize level from the prize fishing table below to be your target prize level. This choice determines the final fishing score you will need in order to catch the fish, and what results a success will yield.
  • Something’s Nibbling: Roll 1d6 and add it to your current fishing score. You can now choose to shift your target prize level up or down by 1. You cannot change it after this step.
  • Reel It In: Roll 1d8 and add it to your current fishing score. If your final fishing score meets or exceeds the fishing score needed for your target prize level, you successfully reel in the result for that prize level. Otherwise, the fish gets away with your bait.

Prize Fishing Table

Prize Level

Fishing Score Needed

Result on a Successful Catch

1

0

Nothing’s Biting. You get your piece of fishing bait back.

2

6

Just a Fish. You catch a common fish that can feed a single creature if cooked. Sells for 1sp.

3

9

That’s a Big One. You catch an impressively large fish, with enough meat to feed 5 creatures if cooked. Sells for 1gp.

4

12

Hearty Morsel. You catch a hearty and flavorful fish, large enough to feed 3 creatures if cooked. Any creature that gets a full meal from this fish has advantage on the first save check it makes before its next long rest. Sells for 3gp.

5

14

Rare Delicacy. You catch a rare fish prized for its unique and memorable flavor. One creature can eat the fish in order to gain a full meal and a +1 to its proficiency bonus until its next long rest. Sells for 10gp.

6

16

One of a Kind. You catch a strange fish with useful magical properties. Roll 1d20. The fish can be used in alchemy as a Beast monster part with a CR equal to the number rolled (minimum of 5). If cooked, one creature can eat the fish in order to get a full meal, the bonuses of both above fish, and their hit point maximum increases by 5 until their next long rest. Sells for 20gp.

7

18

Legendary Catch. You catch a fish of legends, imbued with supernatural power. When eaten, the fish imbues the consumer with temporary magical capabilities. They temporarily gain access to a spell of their choice of a level equal to 1/5th their overall level. They can cast it once per long rest without expending mana. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Presence is their spellcasting attribute for this spell. The magic fades after 1 year or upon eating another Legendary Catch. Sells for 50gp.

name: Explore Area
summary: Search the local area for something in particular.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can explore the 3-mile terrain you were in when you started this rest. Doing so allows you to do one of the following—two, if using a Long Rest Action:

  • Recon: Learn if the area openly contains a certain creature type or species, a type of structure or ruin, a type of business or service, the presence of a certain group or power, the availability of an item or equipment for trade, or the ready availability of food or water.
  • Track: Select a specific creature you know to have been in the environment within the past week and make a Wisdom (Investigation) check to try and determine the creature’s direction. If you beat the DC by 5 or more, you also find a clue about the creature, such as if it’s injured, if it’s been here often, if it’s dropped a clue, etc.
  • Gossip: While resting in a settlement, learn of a local rumor or relevant job posting.
  • Scout: Reveal an inconspicuous aspect of the surrounding environment or culture as determined by the DM. You can’t direct what you’ll find, but you’ll always find something, even if just a few extra coins. For example, a hidden dungeon entrance, a back entrance to a notable structure, a hidden or lost treasure, a creature or group notable or unique to the area, a local creature nest, a surprising food or water source, a cultural practice or expectation you had yet to learn, an event in motion, or simply an item or coin purse left forgotten for you to pocket.
  • Reveal: If you have a hunch that a certain something is hidden in this environment, such as a hidden entrance, invisible object, or illusive creature, you can make a Wisdom (Investigation) check to learn the location or general location of it or its last location. You do not learn that it is not here if you fail the check. DC depends on the environment’s density, the size of the target, and if it’s in motion.
  • Scour: Obtain enough food to feed yourself tonight, if any exist in the environment.

name: Create Pathfinder's Guide
requirements: Pathfinding Kit, Empty Book or Paper
summary: Create a new guidebook with helpful wilderness information.
description:
As a Long Rest Action, you can turn a book or unfilled paper into a Pathfinder’s Guide, adding one chapter to it in the process.
Any creature that can read the Pathfinder’s Guide can study up to 3 chapters of it as a short rest, gaining each chapter’s benefits until their next rest. Bonuses from chapters cannot be stacked, and each physical chapter can only be studied by one creature per rest.

See @Compendium[undertaking.rest-actions.1HMFWYGIRHKP1PBG]{Expand Pathfinder's Guide} for possible chapters you can add.

name: Expand Pathfinder's Guide
summary: Add a new chapter to an existing wilderness guidebook.
description:
With a Pathfinder’s Guide in hand, you can add additional chapters to it as a Long Rest Action, each chapter taking up one sheet of paper (or two pages) each: 

  • Geographical Map: You calligraph a simple map of the area most fitting to a 6-mile diameter.
    • Requirement: Use Explore Area to learn at least three aspects about the area.
    • Effect: While traveling, you move through this area in half the time.
  • Notated Map: You update your Geographical Map to notate local resources and landmarks.
    • Requirements:
      • Have a Geographical Map of the area.
      • Use Explore Area to learn at least five aspects about the area.
    • Effect: While in the area of the map, you have a +2 to finding natural resources and notable unnatural landmarks in the area.
  • Flora Guide: You press the flora into the book, supplementing it with additional sketches and notes about prime spots for it to grow.
    • Requirement: One of the flora from the area in question, pressed into the page when you create this chapter.
    • Effect: You have a +2 to skill checks to find a specific type of flora again.
  • Fauna Guide: You sketch the creature and add notable observations about its biology and behavior.
    • Requirement: Succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Instinct) check toward a creature you can see within 15 ft of you. Upon failure, you cannot try again for the next 1 hour.
    • Effect: You have a +2 to uncontested skill checks against the creature.
      • Fauna Guides cannot be made for societal creatures, such as player races (humans, zhier, chk’tu, etc.).
  • Hunting Guide: You add more details to the creature sketch, highlighting weak points and noting useful hunting tactics.
    • Requirements:
      • Have a Fauna Guide for the creature.
      • You must have slain or defeated a creature of this type at least once.
    • Effect: You have a +1 to attack rolls and damage against a creature, and +2 to checks to harvest anything from it or its corpse.
      • Making a Hunting Guide for societal creatures, such as player races (humans, zhier, chk’tu, etc.), grants no bonus to attack or damage.
  • Star Chart: You chart the stars, noting the directions and angles based on the changing seasons.
    • Requirement: View the stars at night in the area at least once.
    • Effect: While you can see the stars at night, you have both a +2 to checks to navigate and a +1 to Wisdom (Save) checks.

name: Forge Metalwork
summary: Forge armor, a weapon, or another metallic item.
description:
You can create one non-magical armor, weapon, or metalcraft. So long as you have relevant materials equal to ¾ of the item’s cost, you can work on creating the item over the course of short or long rests. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check against DC 8. Each success counts as 1 completed work session, a failure does not. Depending on the item’s actual cost, it takes more work sessions to complete, as determined by the Forging Table below.

  • If you do not have access to a furnace or some similarly hot heat source, increase the DC to 16.

Forging Table

Item Cost

1sp or less

1gp or less

5gp or less

10gp or less

15gp or less

20gp or less

etc.

Sessions

¼

1

1 & ½ 

2

2 & ½ 

3

etc.

name: Weapon Upkeep
summary: Sharpen a weapon, giving it an edge on its damage for a short time.
description: As a Rest Action, you can do general upkeep to a weapon, such as sharpening or tuning, to give it +1 damage on hit. It retains this bonus until it has hit a target three times, or until the next long rest after it has hit a target.

name: Armor Upkeep
summary: Renew a set of armor, bolstering it against the next blow it receives.
description: As a Rest Action, you can do general upkeep, such as hammering out dents, treating cracks, or reinforcing weakened metal, to give a piece of armor +1 AC for the next attack that is made against it.

name: Repair Ammunition
summary: Repair up to 5 pieces of broken ammunition.
description: As a Rest Action, you can repair up to 5 broken ammunition.

name: Apply Basic Disguise
summary: Create a disguise for yourself that shares your race and proportions.
description: As a Rest Action, you can attempt to disguise yourself as any creature of your same race and general body proportions. When you apply this disguise, make an Intelligence (Craft) check. The result of that roll determines the DC that is necessary for others to recognize that the disguise is a fake. The result of that roll, -5, determines the DC that is necessary for others to recognize that the disguise is a fake.

name: Apply Advanced Disguise
summary: Disguise yourself in any way you feasibly can.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can attempt to disguise yourself as any creature that you can reasonably disguise yourself as. When you apply this disguise, make an Intelligence (Craft) check.

  • As part of this disguise, you can make yourself appear about a foot taller or shorter, some pounds thicker or thinner, and can even change your eye color.
  • Attempting to disguise yourself as something with elements that you cannot replicate, such as extra limbs, a different creature size, or an extra head, will automatically fail unless hiding or replacing those elements is part of the disguise.

name: Create Forgery
summary: Attempt to create a convincing forgery of a document or image.
description: As a Rest Action, you can attempt to create a forgery. The forgery can be of a document or other text no longer than a page, an identification, or a simple badge or image. When you do, make an Intelligence (Craft) check. The result of that roll determines the DC that is necessary to recognize that the forgery is a fake.

name: Create Hidden Message
summary: Create a cipher or other form of hidden message.
description: As a Rest Action, you can create a hidden message in text, such as a cipher, encryption, invisible message, and so on. Make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) or Intelligence (Craft) check. The result, -5, becomes the DC to decipher the message.

name: Appraise Item
summary: Estimate the sale value of items you've spent time around.
description: As a Rest Action, you can determine the estimated sale value of up to three items for an area you have spent at least a day in.

name: Create Trinket
summary: Create or continue working on a small non-mechanical trinket.
description:
You can create one non-mechanized trinket or small object. So long as you have relevant materials equal to ¾ of the trinket’s cost, you can work on creating the item over the course of short or long rests. Each Rest Action you spend working on it, make an Intelligence (Craft) check against DC 10. Each success counts as 1 completed work session; a failure does not. Depending on the item’s actual cost, it takes more work sessions to complete.

See @Compendium[undertaking.tables.OANH1Q51JDEB8ETI]{Tinkercraft} table.

name: Create Simple Gadget
summary: Create a common gadget such as a crossbow, lighter, lock, or trap.
description:
As a Rest Action, you can create one common gadget—two as a Long Rest Action. Each gadget can be made from Scrap Metal of an equal GP value:

  • A crossbow (Light, Hand, Heavy, or Repeating)
  • A hunting trap
  • A lighter
  • A lock

name: Create Complex Gadget
summary: Create a complex mechanical gadget from scrap metal.
description:
Over the course of one or more Rest Actions, you can create one intricate item of clockwork, gadgetry, or otherwise. These can vary and some have special effects.

  • Create Clockwork Toy (1 Scrap Metal, 1 rest): You can create a simple clockwork toy that is no larger than a few inches. You decide what it looks like when you make it, but it always has a small winding key to activate it. The toy does up to two simple actions once wound-up, and can only be wound enough to act for up to 1 minute: 
    • Walk 5 ft forward.
    • Make a clicking or dinging noise.
    • Grab and hold an object less than 1lb in size near it.
    • Activate upon motion instead of winding.
    • Light up like a built-in lighter to cast 5 ft of light.
  • Create Timepiece (2 Scrap Metal, 2 rests): You can create a watch or clock that tells the time.
  • Create Impact Capsule (1 Scrap Metal, 1 rest): You can create a capsule that, when a pin is pulled from it, will explode its contents out into a 10 ft radius around where it next impacts. Contents can be anything that can fit inside a baseball, including liquids like water, oil, or potions without the corrupted or thickened modifiers, smoke or gas canisters, even ball bearings or a letter. Impact Capsules break once activated, with all Scrap Metal used to make it too damaged for reusage.
    • Add Lighting Mechanism (1 Scrap Metal, 1 rest): Once you have created an Impact Capsule, you can add a mechanism to cause a spark upon impact, causing anything flammable inside of it to light on fire.
  • Create Music Box (5 Scrap Metal, 3 rests): You can create a box that, when wound, plays a simple tune. You can create new songs for the box by using an additional 1 Scrap Metal.

name: Repair Trinket or Gadget
summary: Repair a damaged trinket or gadget.
description: You can repair a fully broken trinket or gadget at ½ the material cost in ½ the sessions using the @Compendium[undertaking.tables.OANH1Q51JDEB8ETI]{Tinkercraft} table. Partially damaged objects require fewer parts and less time to repair, ask your GM for the difficulty and cost of a partial repair. Intelligence (Craft) checks to repair parts have a DC of 12.

name: Repair Ammunition#2
summary: Repair up to 5 pieces of broken ammunition.
description: As a Rest Action, you can repair up to 5 broken ammunition.

name: Repair Construct
summary: Use your tools and spare metal to restore hit points to a construct.
description: Over a Rest Action, you can repair damage to a Construct using 1 Scrap Metal. Make a DC 10 Intelligence (Craft) check. On success, the Construct restores hit points equal to 1d10 + your Intelligence (Craft) Modifier. On failure, restore 1d4 + your Proficiency instead.

name: Regrow Stinger
summary: Regain the use of your Death Sting.
description: As a Long Rest Action, you focus your body on regrowing your stinger and regain the use of your @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.W2JOTIASQTIRW3IA]{Death Sting} ability.

name: Philosophical Breakthrough
summary: Change the form of belief granted by your Clerical Approach.
description: To change your character’s form of belief, you must reach a philosophical breakthrough as a Long Rest Action. When you do, you lose access to the trait of your previous @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.RVBAX8AXLOK0TRYA]{Clerical Approach}, and may choose another one. This process is mentally taxing, and you cannot make the change again until 1 month after choosing a @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.RVBAX8AXLOK0TRYA]{Clerical Approach}.

name: Heel or Face Turn
summary: Practice a new Gladiatorial Role to adjust your public image.
description: You can change your Gladiatorial Role, but it takes some time to change your public image and get used to the role. You can do so by practicing your new image as a Long Rest Action. When you do, you lose access to the traits of your previous @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.726QUN63DM3JKKPN]{Gladiatorial Role} and may choose another one. If you change @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.726QUN63DM3JKKPN]{Gladiatorial Role} within 1 month of the last change, then you can only gain half heat for 1 week following.

name: Replace Spellbook
summary: Turn a blank book into a new book of spells.
description: Should a Wizard lose their @Compendium[undertaking.abilities.L4TCBW3PWUZVSULN]{Book of Spells} and have to write a new one, they can do so as a Long Rest Action with a new and empty spellbook or any suitable medium—though any improvised option will be less durable than a proper spellbook. During this process, they can copy down all of the spells they know. Spells that you don’t know but had temporarily prepared due to spell scrolls or spellpages that were tucked into your old spellbook are not recovered.

name: Sharing Spells
summary: Copy a spell you know onto a spellpage.
description: While many wizards closely guard their accumulated arcane secrets for fear of what could come about were they to fall into the wrong hands, collaboration between wizards can lead to even greater knowledge. As a Rest Action, you can copy one Wizard spell you know onto a discrete spellpage, should you have one in your possession.
